title: Friday, 7th December 2018

And where do we start? Everything's Deadcat so hard to get much of a steer.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

There's Tesco .....

Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 203.48, up 9.73 (+5.02%), High: 204.00, Low: 197.60, Volume: 8.18m
BE11:11am

Which is on two things. First, it's on UBS saying there's a buyback possible.

Pharma I'd sort of assumed that Trump's need to use the bathroom would be minimal given what comes out of his mouth.
Excel Developer I bought oil. I hope it goes my way
11:11 am
BE11:11am

Second, it's on Exane saying they're too cheap even though forecasts are too high because no one understands Booker.

FATDAZ re the Dax / German Equities I thought this tweet and table was very instructive https://twitter.com/Schuldensuehner/status/1070665501112700928
BE11:12am

Let's start with Item A.

BE11:12am

[W]e posit a reasonable possibility management could commence a share buyback in FY19/20e. After paying a 2x covered dividend (as guided), gearing should fall below the target ceiling. We don't think management intends to retain 'excess' cash on the balance sheet, meaning alternative methods of capital return are possible. We see sufficient firepower for a buyback to be big enough to matter. We believe it would send a strong signal and create shareholder value in a low-risk manner (current discount to NAV greater than 30%). Importantly, we do not believe this narrative is currently part of consensus expectations.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

You'll remember that Tesco's only just been taken off the junk list by Fitch and it still has net debt nudging 3x.

Curious what's Tesco saying about what it expects for Christmas?
BE11:14am

UBS forecasts that to come back to 2.6x next year, and fixed charge cover increases to 3.4x. That, apparently, supports a £1.5bn-plus buyback.

Curious particularly thinking about it's couple of trial low cost stores
Curious (its)
BE11:15am

Oh, and coincidentally, it's in management's interest to retire stock.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Not only would such a buyback be feasible, in our view, but since Oct, board members have bought over half a million pounds of stock, signalling confidence in the outlook and value in equity. A buyback seems directly consistent with a management LTIP now focused on EPS growth vs TSR (as it was historically).

rw42 In today's random learning, PTP time synching is incredibly dangerous.
Pharma @Curious. I've visited a Jack's, and it was quite pleasant. Low prices for the things I wanted (lower than Tesco, and similar to discounters), and self-serve checkouts essentially identical to the ones in Tesco (it was 100% self-serve when I was there).
BE11:16am

Meanwhile, over at Exane, Andrew Gwynn's saying this:

BE11:17am

Momentum rather than valuation is the primary share price driver in food retail, even more so than the market. Given we see risks to 2019/20 consensus, a rapid rebound in Tesco’s shares seems unlikely. However, we’re inline for 2018/19, 2019/20 won’t be reported until April 2020 and we can’t ignore valuation altogether; on our below consensus numbers, Tesco is one of the cheapest stocks in the sector on earnings (c10x 2019/20E EBIT) and cash flow (c8% FCF yield in 2019/20E).

11:17 am
BE11:17am

He is also in the cash return camp.

BE11:18am

The combination of earnings recovery, low capex and dividend cancellation leaves Tesco with low leverage. Even with the dividend now resumed, we see the possibility of cash return in 2019/20 (not included in our forecasts). If we look at lease adjusted net debt / EBITDA, a figure around 2x seems to us to be quite conservative and is the figure applied by Ahold Delhaize when determining its excess capital. In that context
and if our forecasts are right, Tesco could afford a share buyback comfortably over GBP1bn in 2019/20 and potentially as much as GBP2bn. However, it is possible that some of this excess capital is redirected toward reducing the pension deficit.

FATDAZ @excel @ red as i suggested yesterday GS flagged that FFFs that were signaling just one and a bit rate rises in 2019 see this chart https://slack-imgs.com/?c=1&url=https://pbs.twimg.com/media/DtuKm-RW0AAhNbF.jpg

BE11:25am

Drama was yesterday, I guess. Here's UBS:

BE11:25am

OPEC appears to be finding it difficult to choreograph and message the cut as it juggles with the need to get agreement both internally and with OPEC+ (primarily Russia). The OPEC+ talks are expected today and a press conference is scheduled for lunchtime. On the face of it the 1Mb/d cut being discussed, if it excludes 2019 Iranian sanctions effects and is based off October production, is supportive to prices but understandably the market is nervous. Drowned out amid the OPEC noise was a very big crude draw in the delayed DoEs (somewhat balanced off by product builds) but the big news was that the US was reported as a net exporter of liquids - the first time in the modern era.

FATDAZ RE Tesco returning cash I would suggest they hang on to every penny as the balance sheet may need to subsidise the purchase of market share once again in the near future
11:26 am
BE11:26am

Oops, "draw" in that seemed to trigger the raw disclaimer. Apologies, bots.

BE11:26am

And Panmure.

BE11:26am

OPEC deferred the usual post meeting press conference until today amidst conflicting reports about what level of cuts might be agreed,
although the number in play seems to be around 1mmbd, and which countries would participate in them. Agreement appears to be
contingent, at least to some degree, on what the non-OPEC members of OPEC+, mainly meaning Russia, are willing to commit to. Saudi oil
minister, Khalid Al-Falih commented that he was not confident that agreement would be reached and has also indicated that Saudi Arabia will
not make cuts alone.
OPEC last failed to issue a post conference press release in June 2011 which is a measure of how difficult these talks have been. We
anticipated that reaching agreement would be very difficult, likely ending in a fudge, but there is now an increased risk that there may not be
any agreement at all. While markets would probably get some relief in the event of an agreement, a cut of 1mmbd does not look sufficient of
itself to balance the market for next year.

Kiwi-juice comments on Fresenius would be great. Another German Pharma dropping 50%

Guidance is the problem here.

(Apologies for talking in tickers, unavoidable when two companies have basically the same name.)

11:30 am
BE11:31am

Here's Barclays to sum up what's been said.

BE11:31am

Net income guidance: 2019 is expected to be ‘comparable’ to 2018, with the base given as €1,350m-1,365m. This is where investors are likely to have a bit of an issue. If we look at Bloomberg consensus, on a ‘Standard’ basis, which includes 22 forecasts, consensus FY2019 adj net income is €1,365m, i.e. in line with the top of the guidance range. However, if we use the ‘last 28 days’ consensus, this only includes eight estimates, and consensus is €1,436m, which implies a c5% cut. Our current forecast is €1,393m (so a c2.5% cut to our numbers at the middle of the range). The company is citing investment in new products, home dialysis and China (the company announced some small acquisitions here on Wednesday). If management can persuade the street that this is really about investment (rather than underlying pricing pressure), the downside for the shares is likely to be more limited, in our view.

red mkt expectations for lvl of cut quite low now. think 1mln enough to sup crude for now. not ruling out a btd moment tho on release.
Pharma @Flaneur, that article on arrears contains the answer to the increase. In 2008 the repossession rate was 22%, but it is now under 3% - people in trouble with their mortgages are not being kicked out, so the overall numbers carry on rising year by year.
BE11:33am

There's also a laundry list of adjustments. The market's response -- FME's down 8.7% live -- seems to be a bit on surprise at the warning so soon after the last warning.

red saudis in trumps pocket likely til end 2018 poss til end of winter season. after that saudis may be able to do more re cuts.
11:33 am
BE11:33am

Management said they wouldn't guide until the NxStage acquisition was complete, which isn't the case yet.

BE11:33am

Back to Barclays.

BE11:34am

Sorry, not Barclays. JP Morgan Caz. Apologies to both.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Management credibility will likely take another clip following the recent
more substantial warning. Investors are likely to question why today’s news could not have been wrapped into the Q3 release or previous warning. Having said that, investors may view this as a clearing event. We had cited some caution going into the FY19 guidance as there were so many moving parts around the high level of adjustments in FY18. A 4-5% cut may not be seen as ‘that bad’, particularly given FX at current rates is likely to provide an offset that means actual cuts to reported numbers are largely mitigated. The shares are already trading at 8 year PE lows – the call will be critical to seeing if we see further multiple compression.

red re brexit mkt/sterlings could even rally if vote loses by less than 30-40
BE11:35am

And Morgan Stanley.

red bar is so v low there
BE11:36am

As we assess our Outlook for 2019, this announcement suggests that FRE's midterm growth profile is changing and that the consistent and reliable double digit earnings growth the company has been known for, has deteriorated. This is likely to put pressure on FRE's share price not just from the negative earnings revisions, but also potentially from further valuation multiple compression. However, it should be added that none of FRE's three main business units are broken. The greater investment by FMC in areas such dialysis homecare are sensible and we believe the issues around Helios Germany are somewhat home made and can be rectified over a 12 months period. Kabi is a bit more complex, since the move into biosimilars to offset the declining opportunity from patent expiries in injectable generics, comes with uncertainty and execution risk. With consensus earnings revisions likely to fall by -6-8% over the short to medium-term, we expect to see further share price pressure.

Excel Developer nope, not trading Brexit
11:36 am
BE11:37am

And UBS.

Pharma @red, that's only 10-15 tory rebels plus DUP. Doesn't seem likely it will be that close.
BE11:37am

We believe Fresenius Medical’s stock has been heavily penalised for the uncertainty that investors feel over the long-term outlook. Whilst management compared the challenges to those faced in 2013, there is one important difference in our view, the driver of margin declines in 2013 was obvious to all (reimbursement cuts from private insurers and Medicare), today there are a large number of hypothesized explanations: is it investments in care coordination & China, the shift towards home dialysis, negative patient mix as CPA reverses, declining private insurer reimbursement negative patient mix as patients move to competitors, or poor execution in the US?

BE11:37am

However, we remain positive. All of the hypothesized explanations can either be quantified (eg, patient growth is ~3%, down from ~4%) or are not indicative of a structural shift in the market. We continue to see the current headwinds as signalling that North American Dialysis margins are falling from 19% to within the more normal range of 16-18%. The stock appears to be pricing in ~15%, or a structural change in earnings quality, which appears too conservative to us.

A very brief current trading statement, with Primark flagged to have been weak over November.

FATDAZ I wonder if todays CDU leadership elections will help to shape future German opinions on EU
Mr Ticker Cheers BE
Viking1 DWS asset management of DB
BE11:45am

Which isn't a huge surprise given BRC figures told us November was difficult

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Here's Citi.

BE11:46am

[T]here is no quantification but trading has been challenging. Primark U.K. LFL was slowing through 2018 and we were expecting a recovery to c.1% in 1H19. In our view this reflects a weak U.K. consumer pulling back on expenditure rather than the consumer having less money. This is reflected in weak GFK consumer confidence as well. The margin is still expected to improve due to lower markdown and FX benefit which is reassuring. There is no change to expectation for full year profit increase which may imply European trading has been more robust.

BE11:46am

 Potential Black Friday impact — a number of retailers have mentioned that Black Friday has increasingly been an online event and less in-store. The footfall decline for Primark cannot be recaptured online and the non-participation in discounting is unlikely to help.
 Negative read across for sector — Primark has been a clear winner in U.K. clothing and the tough market will likely be felt across all clothing retailers.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

We've only had Black Friday over here for 15 minutes and they're already changing what it means ......

FATDAZ Primark presumably subject to same pressures as other retailers but presumably with less wiggle room on margins given where they price their goods
BE11:47am

Perhaps we can rebrand Cyber Monday as well. Change it to "the day you buy a premium newspaper subscription".

BE11:47am

JP Morgan incoming.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

As is usual for ABF it has released a trading statement ahead of its AGM. Full year guidance at a group level is unchanged: ABF continues to expect FY 19 adjusted EPS to be flat yoy. Outlook comments relating to all non-Retail divisions are also unchanged. However, whilst expectations for an increase in FY Primark profits has been reiterated, ABF is flagging that following in-line sales in the first 8 weeks of the year (slightly positive LFL sales), trading through November has been “challenging, in a tough retail market” (with LFL sales falling
by a high single digit %). Cumulatively, year to date, we understand that LFL sales are slightly negative, and at this stage we would therefore think a negative LFL performance would be a reasonable expectation for the quarter overall ended early January (which is scheduled to be reported on 17 Jan). The weakness has been broad based across markets, not helped by unseasonably warm temperatures in November, as well as perhaps Black Friday causing some diversion of spend into other categories. In the UK at least, this weak Clothing market backdrop was highlighted by the soft BRC data earlier this week and is not new news. On margin, ABF has highlighted careful inventory management at Primark and hence has achieved improved margins: meaning that despite a softer top line it does not expect higher mark down levels nor does it expect profit expectations for the division to change post the statement. Overall, given Primark’s market share gains over the last year, weaker trading here perhaps highlights just how difficult the environment is, particularly for those players weighted into bricks & mortar (i.e. Marks & Spencer). We would expect both ABF and Marks & Spencer to underperform on this update.

red @FATDAZwould be surprised if weak sterling not a drag for them too.

Providing further evidence for our (my) recurring theme that immuno-oncology's a busted flush.

wayneJ And how come customers are compensated for mis-selling by banks but not for 'mis-selling' in referendums?
BE11:53am

Getting one statistically significant result in one indication appears to be nearly irrelevant to any other indication. You're trying a key on different locks and it's really only going to open one of them.

BE11:53am

Here's Jefferies.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

AstraZeneca announced that the Phase III EAGLE trial, which evaluated Imfinzi monotherapy or the Imfinzi / tremelimumab combo in patients with recurrent head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC), that had progressed following platinum-based chemo (regardless of PD-L1 status) has failed to meet its overall survival (OS) primary endpoint. While disappointing, AZN reminds us the recurrent setting represents a difficult-to-treat patient population. The KESTREL study in 1L HNSCC remains ongoing (headlines expected H1’19). Merck & Co’s Keytruda has already demonstrated an OS benefit in the 1L setting. We currently model $500m peak sales for Imfinzi in the overall HNSCC population, and while we don’t specifically split it out, the 1L setting will be the larger contributor to any potential sales. While both these (EAGLE & KESTREL) trials have previously been put on hold for bleeding related side effects, today’s release notes safety and tolerability was consistent with previous experience.

Tom Dalgleish Great analogy BE

Against our earlier hopes for second-tier portfolio companies to step up to diversify dependence on Oxford Nanopore (ON), hopefuls have largely failed to deliver, the listed portfolio drags and the market remains largely uninterested – ominously with the next significant funding beginning to loom. We fear a drift down to the discount 30-40% normal elsewhere: even 20% gives a 95p PT and we move to Underperform.

11:59 am
BE12:00pm

In terms of the other stuff, IP's been reliant on Aim floats. Which have gone like most Aim floats.

BE12:00pm

"its ~20 IPOs stayed close to home, in terms of IP shareholders and UK AIM listings, which have delivered simple average returns of negative 20% since IPO," says Jefferies.

red @FATDAZcommercial owners would rather let things stand empty than budge on rent. often its opm but still hard to understand
BE12:00pm

So:

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Lack of realisations, cash opex of around £40m pa (a ~4% pa drag on NAV growth) and investment rate of c. £100m pa means that with net cash of £156m at end June 2018 (gross cash of £258m) another equity raise is likely 2019 or early 2020. Conditions for this, barring a return to a significant premium to NAV, seem likely to be far less favourable than the rounds in 2014, 2015 and 2017 and the quantum is rising each time.
